abstract: A 2003 California law says Web sites must put links to their privacy policies on their home pages. Google doesn’t do this, saying users can simply search to find out what information it collects about them.
snippet: A 2003 California law says Web sites must put links to their privacy policies on their home pages. Google doesn’t do this, saying users can simply search to find out what information it collects about them.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED 5/30, 8:45 AM After I wrote about Google’s spat with an advertising trade group over the company’s refusal to put a link to its privacy policy on the home page of Google.com, I discovered that there is actually a California law on the subject.

headline.main: Is Google Violating a California Privacy Law?

abstract: Joanne McNabb, the chief of California’s Office of Privacy Protection, said Google is not following her office’s guidelines because it refuses to put a link to its privacy policy on its home page.
snippet: Joanne McNabb, the chief of California’s Office of Privacy Protection, said Google is not following her office’s guidelines because it refuses to put a link to its privacy policy on its home page.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE 6/3 5:45PM: Four privacy groups have sent a letter to Google asking it to place a link to its privacy policy on hits home page. Coverage from CNet and ComputerWorld.

headline.main: California Privacy Chief Says Google Should Improve Disclosure
